{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2018}} {{Infobox military conflict |conflict= Spillover of the Syrian Civil War |partof= the [[Syrian Civil War]], the [[Arab Spring]], and the [[Arab Winter]] |image=Syrian, Iraqi, and Lebanese insurgencies.png |caption=Syria and Iraq 2014-onward war map.
For current military situation as of {{#invoke:Iraq_Syria_map_date|date}}, click version of map without shaded areas: [[Cities and towns during the Syrian Civil War|here for Syria]], [[:Template:Iraqi insurgency detailed map|here for Iraq]], [[:Template:Lebanese Insurgency detailed map|here for Lebanon]], and [[:Template:Syrian, Iraqi, and Lebanese insurgencies detailed map|here for all three in one map]]. |date= 17 June 2011{{spaced ndash}}present ({{Age in years, months, weeks and days|month1=6|day1=17|year1=2011}}) |place= '''[[Syria]]n borders''': [[Lebanon]], [[Turkey]], [[Iraq]], [[Jordan]] and [[Israeli-occupied territories|Israeli-occupied]] [[Golan Heights]]
'''Distant spillover locations (outside of [[Syria]])''': [[Egypt]], [[Libya]], [[Yemen]], [[Kuwait]], [[Bangladesh]], the [[Philippines]], [[Algeria]], [[Pakistan]], [[Southeast Asia]], [[Southern Africa|Southern]] and [[Central Africa]] and [[Europe]] (see [[Wave of Terror in Europe]]) |result= [[List of ongoing armed conflicts|Ongoing]] }} {{Campaignbox Spillover of the Syrian Civil War}} {{Campaignbox Syrian Civil War}} The '''spillover of the Syrian Civil War''' is the impact of the [[Syrian Civil War]] in the [[Arab world]]. Since the first protests during the [[Arab Spring]], the increasingly violent Syrian Civil War has been both a [[proxy war]] for the major Middle Eastern powers, [[Turkey]] and [[Iran]], and a potential launching point for a wider regional war. Fears of the latter were realized when the [[Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant]] (ISIL), a [[Salafi Jihadism|Salafi Jihadist]] militant group and alleged former [[al-Qaeda]] affiliate, established itself in Syria in 2013, and later combined with the [[Iraqi Civil War (2014–present)|Iraqi Civil War]] into a single conflict the following year.http://english.alarabiya.net/en/News/middle-east/2014/04/10/Qaeda-loses-ground-to-rivals-on-Syria-s-Iraq-border.html{{cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/International/isis-iraqs-spoils-tip-balance-eastern-syria/story?id=24128478|title=For ISIS, Iraq's Spoils Could Tip Balance in Eastern Syria|author=ABC News|work=ABC News|accessdate=29 May 2015}}{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/blogs/parallels/2014/06/13/321678737/in-one-map-the-dramatic-rise-of-isis-in-iraq-and-syria|title=In One Map, The Dramatic Rise Of The Islamic State Militants|date=13 June 2014|work=NPR.org|accessdate=29 May 2015}} The spillover of the Syrian Civil War is often dubbed as the [[Arab Winter]]. ==Iraq== {{main article|Iraqi Civil War (2014–present)}} For much of 2012, the Iraqi government had turned a blind eye to the [[Sunni]] and [[Salafist]] militias crossing the border into Syria. This toleration ended when Salafist militias connected to [[al-Qaeda]] ambushed a convoy filled with unarmed Syrian soldiers at [[Akashat ambush|Akashat]] on the Syrian side of the border. This led to greater fighting throughout the country, [[Operation al-Shabah]] in May 2013 in which the [[Iraqi Army]] failed to wipe these militias out and the consolidation of several of them with ISIL. [[Anbar Province]] became a [[Anbar campaign (2013–14)|battle zone]] and an [[April 2014 Iraqi–Syrian border airstrike|airstrike]] in April 2014 was of little use, because in June 2014 ISIL launched an offensive in northern Iraq, taking large swaths of the country and threatening Baghdad itself. In response, Iran reportedly deployed its [[Quds force]] in Iraq,{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/middleeast/iraq/10896670/Obama-ponders-as-Iran-sends-troops-to-Iraq.html|title=Obama ponders as Iran sends troops to Iraq|date=12 June 2014|work=Telegraph.co.uk|accessdate=29 May 2015}} thus turning the conflict into a full-scale war. ===Iraqi-Syrian border incidents=== {{main article|Akashat ambush}} The [[Akashat ambush]] was a well planned assault against a [[Syrian Army]] convoy defended by Iraqi soldiers that took place on 4 March 2013, as the group was travelling in the province of [[Al Anbar Governorate|Anbar]], next to the border with Syria. The [[Islamic State of Iraq]] claimed responsibility for the ambush on 11 March.{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2013/03/201331114024632648.html |title=Al-Qaeda claims killing Syrian troops in Iraq |publisher=Antiwar.com |date=11 March 2013 |accessdate=11 March 2013}} 51 Syrian soldiers were killed in the clashes.{{cite news | url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424127887324281004578352640821817264 | title=Islamists Try to Tighten Grip on Syria Regions | work=Wall Street Journal | date=10 March 2013}}
Another 9 Iraqi soldiers were killed as well from insurgent fire. The attackers carried unknown casualties.{{citation needed|date=December 2013}} In March 2013, a source from Sinjar hospital said that [[Free Syrian Army]] attacked Iraqi soldiers after entering Iraqi territories.https://www.alsumaria.tv/mobile/news/72418/iraq-news/en Since January 2014, The Islamic State has mutated and grown into a massive pseudo country which has taken over much of Iraq and Syria and erased the border between the two countries in a new, multinational war. In June 2016, the New Syrian Army, backed by the United States, overtook ISIL forces in the border town of al-Bukamal. The city is essential to a key route linking eastern Syria to Iraq. However, in the hours following ISIL launched a counteroffensive and retook al-Bukamal, with the New Syrian Army suffering significant casualties.http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2016/06/isil-retakes-syria-border-town-backed-rebels-160629132742057.html As of May 10, 2017, ISIL has maintained control over al-Bukamal and the key route linking Syria and Iraq. ISIL has additionally conducted attacks near the Waled-Tanif Border Crossing to the south, and west of Mosul in the north. The significant territorial control ISIL maintains surrounding al-Bukamal allows for relatively easy passage between the two nations.http://www.understandingwar.org/sites/default/files/Sanctuary%20Map%2010%20MAY.pdf ==Lebanon== {{further information|Syrian Civil War spillover in Lebanon|Hezbollah involvement in the Syrian Civil War}} The Syrian Civil War has led to incidents of sectarian violence in [[North Governorate|northern Lebanon]] between supporters and opponents of the Syrian government, and armed clashes between [[Sunni Islam in Lebanon|Sunnis]] and [[Alawites in Lebanon|Alawites]] in [[Tripoli, Lebanon|Tripoli]].{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/08/24/world/middleeast/syrian-war-plays-out-along-a-street-in-lebanon.html|title=Syrian War Plays Out Along a Street in Lebanon|work=The New York Times|date=24 August 2012|first=Damien|last=Cave}} Fighting between rebels and government forces has spilled into Lebanon on several occasions. The Syrian Air Force has conducted air strikes on targets in Lebanon, while rebels have launched rockets on Hezbollah targets.{{cite news | url=http://www.dailystar.com.lb/News/Politics/2013/Mar-19/210702-lebanon-condemns-syria-airstrike-on-its-territories.ashx#axzz2VjYHFdPG | title=Syria airstrike on Lebanon ‘unacceptable’: Sleiman | work=The Daily Star | date=19 March 2013}} Fighting between supporters of the Sunni sheikh [[Ahmed Al-Assir]], who is against Hezbollah's involvement in Syria, and the Lebanese army has killed at least 15 of its soldiers.http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2013/06/201362471421241300.html Deadly fighting rages in Lebanon 24 June 2013 ===Lebanese–Syrian border=== {{main article|Lebanese–Syrian border clashes}} At the beginning of summer 2012, two [[Hezbollah]] fighters were killed in a clash with Syrian rebels who were on Lebanese territory.{{cite web|url=http://www.northjersey.com/news/international/171434781_Hezbollah_Increases_Support_for_Syrian_Regime__U_S__and_Lebanese_Officials_Say__Beirut_.html?c=y&page=1 |title=Hezbollah Increases Support for Syrian Regime, U.S. and Lebanese Officials Say (Beirut) |publisher=Northjersey.com |date=26 September 2012 |accessdate=25 December 2012}} On 17 September, [[Syria]]n [[Ground-attack aircraft]] fired three missiles {{convert|500|m|ft}} over the border into Lebanese territory near [[Arsal]]. It was suggested that the jets were chasing rebels in the vicinity. The attack prompted Lebanese [[president]] [[Michel Sleiman]] to launch an investigation, whilst not publicly blaming Syria for the incident.{{cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/world/2012/09/18/syrian-jets-hit-lebanese-territory-near-border/#ixzz27JvfB9lg |title=Syrian jets hit Lebanese territory near border, 18 September 2012 |publisher=Foxnews.com |date=18 September 2012 |accessdate=25 December 2012}} On 22 September 2012, a group of armed members of the [[Free Syrian Army]] attacked a border post near [[Arsal]]. This was reported to be the second incursion within a week. The group were chased off into the hills by the [[Lebanese Army]], who detained and later released some rebels due to pressure from dignified locals. Michel Sleiman praised the actions taken by the military as maintaining Lebanon's position being “neutral from the conflicts of others". He called on border residents to “stand beside their army and assist its members.” [[Syria]] has repeatedly called for an intensified crackdown on rebels that it claims are hiding in Lebanese border towns.{{cite web|url=http://www.dailystar.com.lb/News/Politics/2012/Sep-23/188927-lebanese-president-praises-army-response-to-fsa-attack.ashx#ixzz27JxWSuyo |title=(Lebanon), Lebanese president praises Army response to FSA attack, 23 September 2012 |publisher=The Daily Star |accessdate=25 December 2012}}{{cite news|url=http://cnnespanol.cnn.com/2012/09/22/rebeldes-sirios-atacan-un-puesto-del-ejercito-en-territorio-de-libano/ |title=Rebeldes sirios atacan un puesto del Ejército en territorio de Líbano, CNN Espanol, Alkhshali Hamdi, Amir Ahmed, Mohammed Tawfeeq, Ben Brumfield and Joe Sterling, 22 September 2012 |publisher=Cnnespanol.cnn.com |accessdate=25 December 2012}} On 11 October 2012, four shells fired by the Syrian military hit [[Masharih al-Qaa]], where previous shelling incidents have caused fatalities. Lebanon's position of ignoring the attacks and dissociating itself from the conflict remained unchanged.{{citation needed|date=December 2013}} In October 2012 [[Hassan Nasrallah]] denied Hezbollah members were fighting alongside the Syrian army, but that Lebanese in Syria were only protecting Lebanese inhabited villages from the Free Syrian Army.{{cite web|url=http://www.naharnet.com/stories/en/57430-report-5-000-pro-hizbullah-fighters-defending-lebanese-inhabited-border-towns-in-syria|title=Report: 5,000 Pro-Hizbullah Fighters Defending Lebanese-Inhabited Border Towns in Syria|publisher=Naharnet|accessdate=20 October 2012}} In August 2014, the Syrian air force bombed the Lebanese side of the border.{{cite web|url=http://www.dailystar.com.lb/News/Lebanon-News/2014/Aug-27/268663-syria-warplanes-bomb-lebanon-border-region.ashx#axzz3BQqtSY8q|title=Syria warplanes bomb Lebanon border region|work=The Daily Star Newspaper – Lebanon|accessdate=13 November 2014}} In December of that year, they used barrel bombs on suspected rebel installations northwest of Arsal.{{cite web|url=http://www.middleeasteye.net/news/three-lebanese-killed-syrian-raid-border-area-1754270169|title=Three Lebanese killed by Syrian raid on border town|work=Middle East Eye}} ===Lebanon vs. ISIL and al-Nusra Front=== {{main article|Battle of Arsal}} Starting in June 2014, Hezbollah began battling with Islamists along the Lebanese border, who had crossed into Lebanon several times and threatened to throw the country into full-scale war. From 2–5 August 2014, the [[Lebanese Army]] clashed with Syrian gunmen in the town of [[Arsal]], which left over a hundred soldiers on both sides dead.{{cite web|url=http://www.naharnet.com/stories/en/141658-army-announces-death-of-10-troops-in-arsal-sends-reinforcements-as-residents-flee-en-masse |title=Army Retakes Posts in Arsal, Says 10 Troops Killed as 'Humanitarian Truce' Reportedly Reached — Naharnet |publisher=Naharnet.com |date=3 August 2014 |accessdate=12 August 2014}} On 21 August 2014, the [[al-Nusra Front]] invaded Lebanon near Arsal and the Bekaa Valley town of Al-Fakiha. Following a battle between them and Hezbollah, seven Hezbollah fighters and 32 Syrian terrorists died in clashes around the Syrian village of Nahleh, just over the border from Arsal.http://www.dailystar.com.lb/News/Lebanon-News/2014/Jul-17/264184-hezbollah-nusra-front-clash-near-lebanon-border Dozens of hostages were taken back to Syria during the above-mentioned battle of Arsal. After fruitless negotiations, the Lebanese cabinet voted to authorize the army to invade Syria to free them on 4 September 2014,{{cite web|url=http://www.dailystar.com.lb/News/Lebanon-News/2014/Sep-05/269635-military-option-on-table-to-free-hostages.ashx#axzz3BQqtSY8q|title=Military option on table to free hostages|work=The Daily Star Newspaper – Lebanon}} something that they have yet to do. There was another attempted invasion of Lebanon by a joint ISIL-Nusra force in early October, which was beaten back by Hezbullah,{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-29498972|title=BBC News – Hezbollah repel al-Nusra attack on Lebanon-Syria border|work=BBC News|accessdate=13 November 2014}} and in January 2015. In December 2015, after over a year and a half in captivity, Lebanese troops held prisoner by Al Nusra were exchanged for prisoners held in Lebanon.{{Cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2015/12/lebanese-hostages-released-prisoner-swap-151201072408599.html|title=Lebanese army and al-Nusra Front conduct prisoner swap|website=www.aljazeera.com|access-date=10 August 2016}} ===Hezbollah vs. ISIL=== In June 2015, the [[Hezbollah]] claimed that it was in the midst of a major battle with ISIL, which it claimed had invaded Lebanon and seized territory.{{cite web|url=http://www.thenational.ae/world/middle-east/hizbollah-declares-war-on-isil|title=Hizbollah declares war on ISIL|author=Josh Wood|work=The National}} On 21 July 2017 Hezbollah along with the Syrian Army declared an offensive on the seized territories by insurgents. On 22 July 2017 Hezbollah officials claimed capturing several points of the re-seized territories. ==Turkey== {{main article|Turkish involvement in the Syrian Civil War}} With a thousand-mile border with Syria and Iraq, there have been a number of incidents involving this nation with various factions in the conflicts south of the border. ===Syrian–Turkish border clashes=== {{main article|Syrian–Turkish border clashes during the Syrian Civil War}} Openly supporting the overthrow of [[Bashar al-Assad]] Turkey permitted the establishment of a "jihadist highway" where rebels of all stripes, including ISIL, were permitted to cross both supplies and personnel South of the border.{{cite web|url=http://www.dailysabah.com/opinion/2014/09/30/empathy-might-work-turkey-delivers-tanks-to-isis|title='Empathy' might work: Turkey delivers tanks to ISIS – Opinion – Daily Sabah|work=dailysabah.com|accessdate=13 November 2014}} There were various incidents including the shooting down of a Turkish Air Force jet by Syria which killed the 2 pilots and also the shooting down of a Syrian Air Force jet by Turkey, and a February 2015 raid by the Turkish army to evacuate a tiny exclave in Syria. ===Turkey and ISIL=== {{main article|Turkey–ISIL conflict}} Turkey had been allegedly supporting ISIL throughout its many incarnations as a "lesser evil" against the Assad government.{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/david-l-phillips/research-paper-isis-turke_b_6128950.html|title=Research Paper: ISIS-Turkey List|work=The Huffington Post|accessdate=29 January 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2014/09/11/turkey-joins-the-coalition-of-the-unwilling.html|title=Why Turkey Is Sitting Out the ISIS War|work=The Daily Beast|accessdate=29 January 2015}} This to some extent began to change with the [[2013 Reyhanlı bombings]] and a retaliatory airstrike in January 2014. ISIL shook this off and began its conquest of northern Iraq, followed by consolidation of territories in Northern Syria. In the summer of 2014 it began taking over the border area with Turkey, leading to hundreds of thousands of refugees coming north along the border, riots,{{cite web|url=http://www.todayszaman.com/latest-news_16-dead-across-turkey-as-fate-of-kobani-stirs-up-tensions_360981.html|title=22 killed in protests against ISIL siege of Kurdish town|date=9 October 2014|work=TodaysZaman|accessdate=13 November 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141010194804/http://www.todayszaman.com/latest-news_16-dead-across-turkey-as-fate-of-kobani-stirs-up-tensions_360981.html|archivedate=10 October 2014|df=dmy-all}} the use of teargas, rubber bullets, and live ammunition, as well the end of the truce with the [[PKK]]. A vote to authorize military action was passed by the Turkish parliament on 2 October 2014. However, it had no follow-through and [[2014 Kurdish riots in Turkey|further rioting]]{{cite web|url=http://rt.com/news/193844-protests-turkey-isis-kurdish/|title=Tear gas, clashes, fatality: Anti-ISIS rally in Turkey turns violent (PHOTOS)|publisher=|accessdate=13 November 2014}} ensued through much of Turkey's cities as the government demanded more and more conditions to join in the war. The riots intensified and several dozen protesters have been killed.{{Citation needed|date=November 2014}} The relationship between ISIL and Turkey deteriorated during the spring and summer of 2015, leading to sniping at the border and airstrikes by the Turks. ===Siege of the Süleyman Shah Tomb=== On 22 February 2015, the Turkish army invaded Syria via Kobani and drove to the Süleyman Shah Tomb, which was dismantled and brought back to Turkey. The 40 guards, who were due to return home months before, were also rescued. About 100 military vehicles, including 39 tanks, were involved along with 572 military personnel, one of which was killed in an accident.{{cite web|url=http://www.dailystar.com.lb/Arts-and-Ent/Culture/2015/Feb-22/288280-turkey-evacuates-troops-guarding-tomb-inside-syria.ashx#sthash.3n0dA379.dpuf|title=Turkey evacuates troops guarding tomb inside Syria|work=The Daily Star Newspaper – Lebanon|accessdate=29 May 2015}} Thirty to thirty-six Turkish soldiers were stationed there to guard the tomb. An attack on the tomb, considered Turkish territory under a 1921 Franco-Turkish agreement, was under threat earlier in the year, prompting the government to declare that it would retaliate against any such attack, and would serve as a [[casus belli]]. The Syrian government said the raid was{{cite web|url=http://www.dailystar.com.lb/News/Middle-East/2015/Feb-22/288305-syria-condemns-turkeys-flagrant-aggression-in-north.ashx#sthash.mn9yNy3I.dpuf|title=Syria condemns Turkey's 'flagrant aggression' in north|work=The Daily Star Newspaper – Lebanon|accessdate=29 May 2015}} an act of "flagrant aggression" and that it would hold Ankara responsible for its repercussions. ===Russian warplane downing=== {{main article|2015 Russian Sukhoi Su-24 shootdown}} On 24 November 2015, a Russian warplane was shot down in the Syrian-Turkey border area. Turkey claims the plane violated Turkish airspace, a claim Russia denies.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-34907983|title=Turkey 'downs Russian warplane on Syria border'|work=BBC News|accessdate=24 November 2015}} Early reports from multiple Russian news agencies indicated that the plane had been downed by a ground-based strike from Syrian rebels, but Russian officials later confirmed the Turkish reports that the plane had been downed by Turkish fighter jets. According to Turkish officials, the Russian jet, an [[Sukhoi Su-24|SU-24]], was shot down by two Turkish [[General Dynamics F-16 Fighting Falcon|F-16]] jets after multiple requests (10 requests in a five-minute span) for the Russian jet to change its course. Turkey maintains that the Russian jet violated its airspace, flying over Turkish territory despite warnings to change course, while Russia states that its jet never entered Turkish airspace and was over Syria the whole time. Turkey produced a graphic showing the Russian plane's flight pattern, which appears to show it crossing the southern tip of [[Hatay Province]] before being shot down and crashing near [[Turkmen Mountain]] near the Syria-Turkey border.{{cite news|last1=Whittaker|first1=Francis|last2=Melville-Smith|first2=Alicia|title=Russian Jet Downed Near Turkey-Syria Border|url=https://www.buzzfeed.com/franciswhittaker/warplane-crashes-near-turkeys-border-with-syria#.skMd8XV6pg|accessdate=24 November 2015|agency=Buzzfeed News|date=24 November 2015}} Turkey had previously warned Russia about violations to Turkish airspace, and had also warned them off strikes against civilian [[Syrian Turkmen]] living along the Turkish border.{{cite news|title=Turkey 'shoots down Russian warplane on Syria border'|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-34907983|accessdate=24 November 2015|agency=BBC|date=24 November 2015}} Russia has steadfastly maintained "throughout its flight, the aircraft remained exclusively above Syrian territory." In response, Russian president [[Vladimir Putin]] stated that the attack was "a stab in the back by the accomplices of terrorists." ===Kurdish conflict=== {{main article|Kurdish–Turkish conflict (2015–present)}} The 2015 conflict between Turkey and the PKK broke out following two year-long peace negotiations, which began in late 2012, but failed to progress in light of the growing tensions on border with Syria in late 2014, when the [[Siege of Kobani]] created an unprecedented wave of Kurdish refugees into Turkey. Some of the Kurds accused Turkey of assisting the [[Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant]] (ISIL) during the crisis, resulting in widespread [[2014 Kurdish riots in Turkey|Kurdish riots in Turkey]] involving dozens of fatalities. The tensions further escalated in summer 2015 with the [[2015 Suruç bombing|20 July bombing in Suruç]], allegedly executed by an ISIL-affiliated Turkish group against Kurdish supporters. On 21 July, the [[Kurdistan Workers' Party|PKK]] killed a Turkish soldier and wounded 2 more in [[Adıyaman]].{{cite web|url=http://www.hurriyet.com.tr/adiyaman-da-catisma-1-sehit-2-yarali-29593577|title=Adıyaman’da çatışma: 1 şehit, 2 yaralı|last=|first=|date=21 July 2015|website=[[Hurriyet]]|publisher=DHA|access-date=2 March 2016}} Some PKK supporters then claimed responsibility for the 23 July killing of two Turkish police officers in Ceylanpinar,{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2015/07/kurdish-group-claims-revenge-murder-turkish-police-150722132945249.html|title=Kurdish group claims 'revenge murder' on Turkish police|website=www.aljazeera.com|access-date=2 March 2016}} describing it as a retaliation.{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2015-09-21/tensions-rise-in-kurdish-turkey-after-military-crackdown/6790752|title=Turkish crackdown on Kurds leaves death and destruction in border town of Cizre|work=ABC News|accessdate=27 September 2015}} ==Jordan== {{main article|Jordanian–Syrian border incidents during the Syrian Civil War}} There have been several incidents on the 375 km long border between Syria and Jordan.{{cite web|url=http://www.dailystar.com.lb/News/Middle-East/2014/Jun-14/260116-jordan-4-vehicles-destroyed-on-syria-border.ashx#ixzz34ciqgxnK|title=Jordan: 4 vehicles destroyed on Syria border|work=The Daily Star Newspaper – Lebanon|accessdate=29 May 2015}} Jordan hosts nearly 600,000 registered Syrian refugees—although Jordanian officials say the total number is 1.4 million.{{Cite web|url=http://www.jordantimes.com/news/local/higher-population-council-says-syrian-refugees-number-14-million|title=Higher Population Council says Syrian refugees number 1.4 million|date=24 September 2014|access-date=10 August 2016}} Heavy shelling aimed at [[Daraa]] in Syria has accidentally hit the Jordanian side of the border from time to time, usually causing only light or no damage.{{cite web|url=http://jordantimes.com/clashes-erupt-anew-along-syria-border|title=Clashes erupt anew along Syria border|work=Jordan Times|accessdate=29 May 2015}} However, there have been [[Jordanian–Syrian border incidents during the Syrian Civil War|occurrences]] where armed men have been killed or injured in engagements with Jordanian border patrols soldiers.{{cite web|url=http://www.naharnet.com/stories/en/183098-rocket-fired-from-syria-kills-one-in-jordan|title=Rocket Fired from Syria Kills One in Jordan|work=Naharnet}} In April 2014, the [[Jordanian Air Force]] launched [[April 2014 Jordanian–Syrian border airstrike|an airstrike]] on soldiers trying to illegally cross the border from Syria. Since then, attempted militant infiltration into Jordan has become commonplace.{{cite web|url=http://www.albawaba.com/main-headlines/jordan-syria-border-577250|title=One killed, several wounded in Jordan-Syria border clashes|work=Al Bawaba|accessdate=13 November 2014}} Some of this was due to the return of Jordanian citizens who, as Jihadists, went to fight in Syria for a while and decided to go home for various reasons.{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2014/04/17/us-jordan-syria-militants-insight-idUSBREA3G16H20140417|title=Jordanian jihadis returning from Syria war rattle U.S.-aligned kingdom|work=Reuters|accessdate=13 November 2014}} According to reports, there are over 2000 Jordanian Jihadis fighting in Syria. Over a hundred have been arrested and charged for crossing the border to fight, which is illegal in Jordan. Since October 2014, Jordan has been an active part of the anti-ISIS coalition, contributing to the American-led campaign of airstrikes. Two incidents occurred in January 2016. On 23 January Jordanian armed forces spokesman stated that a total of 36 armed men tried to infiltrate the border and an engagement with Jordanian border patrol left 12 dead while the rest retreated back into Syria. They were found to have 2,000,000 drug pills. The spokesperson also stated that "Jordan will not tolerate any infiltration attempt and will strike with an iron fist to whoever tries to disrupt Jordanian national security".{{cite web|url=http://www.jordantimes.com/news/local/army-kills-12-infiltrators-syria-border|title=Army kills 12 infiltrators on Syria border|work=Jordan Times}} On 25 January, two armed men tried to infiltrate the borders and were killed. They were found to have 2600 palm-sized bags of cannabis and 2.4 million Captagon pills.{{cite web|url=http://khaberni.com/more-163222-1-%D8%AD%D8%B1%D8%B3%20%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%AD%D8%AF%D9%88%D8%AF%20%D9%8A%D9%82%D8%AA%D9%84%20%D9%85%D9%87%D8%B1%D8%A8%D9%8A%D9%92%D9%86|title=خبرني : نبض الشارع : حرس الحدود يقتل مهربيْن|publisher=Khaberni|accessdate=25 January 2016}} ==Syrian-Israeli ceasefire line== {{main article|Israeli–Syrian ceasefire line incidents during the Syrian Civil War}} On 25 September 2012, several mortar shells landed in the [[Israeli-occupied territories|Israeli-occupied]] [[Golan Heights]], landing in an open area adjacent to the border fence.{{cite web|url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4285819,00.html |title=Mortar shells land in northern Golan Heights|publisher=Ynetnews|date=25 September 2012 |accessdate=14 November 2012}} Overall, throughout October and early November, several Syrian mortar and light artillery shells hit the Golan Heights. One mortar round may have been responsible for a [[brush fire|brushfire]] that erupted in the area. On 3 November, three Syrian tanks entered the [[demilitarized zone]] in the central Golan Heights as a number of mortar shells were fired into the area.{{cite web|url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4300606,00.html |title=3 Syrian tanks enter demilitarized zone in Golan Heights|publisher=Ynetnews|date=3 November 2012 |accessdate=14 November 2012}} On 5 November, an Israeli army jeep was damaged by Syrian army gunfire as it patrolled the border.{{cite web|url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4301538,00.html |title=IDF jeep hit by Syrian gunfire; none injured|publisher=Ynetnews|date=5 November 2012 |accessdate=14 November 2012}} On 11 November, after a Syrian 120mm mortar round hit the eastern Golan Heights, the Israeli army responded by firing an electro-optic anti-tank missile in the direction of a Syrian mortar crew, but they deliberately missed them, intending it as a warning shot.{{cite news|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2012/11/20121111121454453745.html |title=Israeli army fires 'warning shots' at Syria|work=Al Jazeera|date=11 November 2012 |accessdate=14 November 2012}} On 12 November, another Syrian mortar shell struck the Golan Heights, and Israeli tanks deployed along the border responded by targeting two Syrian mortar launchers. A direct hit was confirmed.{{cite web|url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4304381,00.html |title=IDF retaliates against Syrian mortar fire|publisher=Ynetnews|date=12 November 2012 |accessdate=14 November 2012}} A shell fired from Syria, where insurgents and government troops are locked in fierce fighting, exploded in the Israeli-occupied part of the [[Golan Heights]] plateau on Sunday, 14 July 2013.{{citation needed|date=December 2013}} On 22 and 23 June 2015 two ambulances transporting wounded Syrian rebels were attacked by [[Druze]] protesters in the Golan Heights. One of the injured persons was killed in the incident.{{cite news|url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4671371,00.html|title=Wounded Syrian killed when Druze lynch mob attacks IDF ambulance|date=23 June 2015|accessdate=25 June 2015}} The attacks followed an interview with a rebel who had been treated in Israel and promised to come back to Syria to fight against the Druze minority.{{cite news|url=http://www.jpost.com/Israel-News/Politics-And-Diplomacy/Talk-of-Israel-aiding-Nusra-Front-in-Syria-is-insane-Liberman-says-406859|title=Druse living under Israeli rule in the Golan Heights believe that some of the Syrians being treated at Israeli hospitals are Nusra Front gunmen|date=23 June 2015|accessdate=25 June 2015}} On 10 February 2018, an [[Iran]]ian drone [[February 2018 Israel–Syria incident|was reported to have entered]] Israeli airspace, which was shot down by the [[Israeli Air Force]]. In retaliation, the IAF struck Iranian targets inside Syria. During the attack on the Iranian targets, Syrian anti-air defense systems shot down an Israeli [[General Dynamics F-16 Fighting Falcon|F-16]] fighter jet.{{Cite news|url=http://www.jpost.com/Arab-Israeli-Conflict/Israeli-Air-Force-strikes-Iranian-targets-in-Syria-542191|title=Israel strikes Iranian targets in Syria, IAF F-16 shot down|work=The Jerusalem Post {{!}} JPost.com|access-date=2018-02-10}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.rt.com/news/418388-israeli-jet-crashes-syria-fire/|title=Israeli F-16 fighter jet shot down amid Syrian anti-air fire, pilots safe - IDF|work=RT International|access-date=2018-02-10|language=en-US}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-43014081|title=Israeli jet downed by Syrian fire - army|date=2018-02-10|work=BBC News|access-date=2018-02-10|language=en-GB}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.haaretz.com/israel-news/red-alert-sirens-sound-heavy-aerial-activity-in-northern-israel-1.5806508|title=Israel Downs Iranian Drone, Strikes Syria; Israeli F-16 Shot Down, Pilots Safe|last=Kubovich|first=Yaniv|date=2018-02-10|work=Haaretz|access-date=2018-02-10|last2=Shpigel|first2=Noa|language=en|last3=Khoury|first3=Jack}} 2 hours after the downing of the jet, Israel began attacking additional targets inside Syria.{{Cite news|url=https://www.rt.com/news/418391-syria-israel-raids-damascus/|title=Syrian air defenses respond to new Israeli raids near Damascus – state TV|work=RT International|access-date=2018-02-10|language=en-US}} ==Distant spillover locations== ===Egypt=== {{main article|Sinai insurgency|Insurgency in Egypt (2013–present)}} ===Libya=== {{main article|Libyan Civil War (2014–present)|Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant in Libya}} The takeover of the city of [[Derna, Libya|Derna]] in [[Cyrenaica]], [[Libya]] by the self-declared [[Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant]] (ISIL) took place in late 2014. In November 2014, Wilayat Darnah (the province of Darnah){{cite news|last1=Zelin|first1=Aaron Y.|title=The Islamic State's First Colony in Libya|url=http://www.washingtoninstitute.org/policy-analysis/view/the-islamic-states-first-colony-in-libya|accessdate=21 November 2014|work=The Washington Institute|date=10 October 2014}} or Wilayat Barqah (Province of Eastern Libya) was declared an integral part the so-called "Islamic State". ISIL has now taken complete control of the eastern Libyan coastal city with a population of 100,000.{{cite news|last1=Ernst|first1=Douglas|title=Islamic State takes Libyan city; 100K under terror group’s control as chaos spreads|url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2014/nov/18/islamic-state-takes-libyan-city-100k-under-terror-/|accessdate=21 November 2014|work=[[The Washington Times]]|date=18 November 2014}} ISIL in Libya posted a video online on 15 February 2015 depicting the killing of 21 [[Egypt]]ian [[Copts]]. The video bore similarities to previous videos showing the "execution" of [[Western world|Western]] and [[Japan]]ese hostages, including the orange jumpsuits worn by the victims and the method of killing by [[decapitation]].{{cite news|url=http://time.com/3710610/libya-coptic-christians-isis-egypt/|agency=TIME|title=Beheading of Coptic Christians in Libya Shows ISIS Branching Out|date=15 February 2015|accessdate=17 February 2015}} Egypt responded to the video by [[2015 Egyptian military intervention in Libya|launching airstrikes]] against targets in Derna.{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/feb/16/egypt-air-strikes-target-isis-weapons-stockpiles-libya|agency=The Guardian|title=Egyptian air strikes in Libya kill dozens of Isis militants|date=16 February 2015|accessdate=17 February 2015}}{{cite news|url=http://www.libyaherald.com/2015/02/16/breaking-news-more-egyptians-being-kidnapped/#axzz3S54HzxID|agency=Libya Herald|title=More Egyptians being kidnapped|date=16 February 2015|accessdate=17 February 2015}} ===Yemen=== {{main article|Yemeni Civil War (2015–present)}} ===Kuwait=== {{see also|2015 Kuwait mosque bombing}} On 26 June 2015, ISIL militants blew up a Shiite mosque in [[Kuwait City]] killing dozens and injuring hundreds.{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2015/06/isil-claim-responsibility-kuwait-shia-mosque-attack-150626124555564.html|title=ISIL claims responsibility for Kuwait Shia mosque blast|publisher=|accessdate=29 June 2015}} ===France=== {{main article|Islamic terrorism in Europe (2014–present)|France-ISIL conflict}} A campaign of [[Islamist]] attacks occurred in France, beginning with the [[January 2015 Île-de-France attacks|Île-de-France attacks]] on 7 January 2015, between the French Government and ongoing [[Terrorism|terrorist acts]] committed by [[Jihadism|jihadist]] terror groups like [[al-Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula|AQAP]] and [[Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant|ISIL]], or isolated individuals who sympathise with the jihadist movement. Since 2015 and until July 2016, eight Islamic terrorist incidents have occurred in France, including fatal attacks in Île-de-France, [[Saint-Quentin-Fallavier attack|Saint-Quentin-Fallavier]] and [[November 2015 Paris attacks|Paris]]. [[November 2015 Paris attacks|The November 2015 attacks in Paris]] were motivated by ISIL as a "retaliation" for the French role in Syrian Civil War and Iraqi War.[https://www.wsj.com/articles/paris-attacks-were-an-act-of-war-by-islamic-state-french-president-francois-hollande-says-1447498080] "Islamic State claimed responsibility for the attacks on a social media account, but didn’t provide specific information that would allow the claim to be verified. It said the attacks were retaliation for French airstrikes against the group in Syria and Iraq." ===Bangladesh=== A majority of [[attacks by Islamic extremists in Bangladesh]] since October 2015 have been claimed by ISIL. In November 2015, the ISIL magazine Dabiq published an article calling for the "revival of jihad in [[Bengal]]".{{Cite web|url=http://www.thedailystar.net/frontpage/bangladesh-saw-rise-attacks-1234156|title=Bangladesh saw rise in attacks|date=3 June 2016|access-date=10 August 2016}} Since then, radical Islamic militants have assassinated Bangladeshi secularists, atheists, writers, bloggers, LGBT activists, Sufi and liberal Muslims, Hindu and Buddhist priests and Christian missionaries, as well as foreign expatriates from Europe and East Asia. On 1 July 2016, [[2016 Gulshan attack|six gunmen stormed an upmarket restaurant]] in Bangladesh's capital Dhaka, killed customers of various nationalities and held hostages for nearly 12 hours, before the Bangladesh army ended the siege. ISIL claimed credit for the attack and reportedly released photographs of both the gunmen and victims from inside the restaurant during the hostage crisis.{{Cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2016/07/01/gunmen-attack-restaurant-in-diplomatic-quarter-of-bangladeshi-ca/|title=20 hostages killed in 'Isil' attack on Dhaka restaurant popular with foreigners|access-date=10 August 2016}} The government of Bangladesh, however, has refuted ISIL claims and denies the group has any presence in the country. It has instead blamed local terrorist outfits, particularly the [[Jamaat-ul-Mujahideen Bangladesh]] (JMB) and the [[Ansarullah Bangla Team]], both of which have been linked to the country's far-right Islamist opposition parties. ===Philippines=== {{main article|Moro conflict}} ===Afghanistan=== {{main article|War in Afghanistan (2015–present)}} ===Caucasus=== {{main article|Insurgency in the North Caucasus}} ===South and Central Africa=== {{main article|Boko Haram insurgency}} ===Algeria=== {{main article|Jund al-Khilafah}} ===Pakistan=== {{main article|War in North-West Pakistan}} ==See also== {{Portal|Syrian Civil War}} {{Div col|colwidth=20em}} *[[Timeline of the Syrian Civil War]] *[[Anbar clashes (2013–14)]] *[[European migrant crisis]] *[[Refugees of the Syrian Civil War]] *[[Islamic terrorism in Europe (2014–present)]] *[[Iran–Saudi Arabia proxy conflict]] *[[List of modern conflicts in the Middle East]] *[[List of ongoing military conflicts]] *[[List of wars by death toll]] *[[List of wars involving Syria]] *[[List of wars involving Iraq]] *[[List of wars involving Iran]] *[[List of wars involving Iraqi Kurdistan]] *[[List of wars involving Israel]] *[[List of wars involving Jordan]] *[[List of wars involving Lebanon]] *[[List of wars involving Saudi Arabia]] *[[List of wars involving Turkey]] {{div col end}} {{clear}} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} {{Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant |state=collapsed}} {{Islamic terrorism in Europe}} {{Post-Cold War Asian conflicts}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Spillover of the Syrian Civil War}} [[Category:Spillover of the Syrian Civil War| ]] [[Category:Consequences of the Syrian Civil War]] [[Category:Foreign relations of Syria]] [[Category:Conflicts in 2014]] [[Category:Conflicts in 2015]] [[Category:2016 in the Syrian Civil War]]

{{Refimprove|date=July 2013}}{{redirect|thestandard.com|other uses|The Standard (disambiguation)}} {{italic title}} '''''The Industry Standard''''' is a U.S. news web site dedicated to technology business news, part of [[InfoWorld]], a news website covering technology in general. It is a revival of a weekly [[magazine]] based in [[San Francisco]] which was published between 1998 and 2001.
==Print magazine, 1998-2001== ''The Industry Standard'' called itself "the newsmagazine of the Internet economy", and it specialized in areas where business and the Internet overlapped. Like ''[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]]'', ''[[Red Herring (magazine)|Red Herring]]'', and (later) ''[[Business 2.0]]'', it was part of a breed of late 1990s publications that filled a gap in technology coverage left by mainstream media at the time.
The magazine, which was owned by the technology publishing company [[International Data Group|IDG]], was in many ways the brainchild of [[John Battelle]], who had been a journalist at ''Wired'' both in the [[United States]] and the [[United Kingdom]]. Jonathan Weber was its editor-in-chief. The magazine also ran a web site, thestandard.com.
Beginning in 1999, ''The Standard'' began selling a large number of advertising pages in the magazine, and began to be referred to as "the bible" of the Internet economy. In 2000, it sold more ad pages than any magazine in America, and launched that year a European edition. However, as the [[dot-com boom]] failed, sales of the magazine began to shrink, and it went into bankruptcy in August 2001.<ref>{{cite news|last=Wolverton|first=Troy|url=http://news.com/2100-1023-271755.html|title=The Industry Standard to stop publishing|work=CNET News.com|date=August 17, 2001}}</ref> One of The Standard's writer/editors, [[James Ledbetter]], published a book in 2003 about the magazine's rise and fall; entitled ''Starving to Death on $200 Million: The Short, Absurd Life of The Industry Standard''.
==Website, 2008-present== IDG relaunched ''The Industry Standard'' as an online-only publication in 2008.<ref>{{cite news|last=Stone|first=Brad|url=http://bits.blogs.nytimes.com/2007/10/02/bubblewatch-the-industry-standard-is-coming-back/|title=Bubblewatch: The Industry Standard Is Coming Back|work=The New York Times|date=October 2, 2007}}</ref> The site featured technology industry news and an interactive section where visitors could make predictions about the future of the tech industry.<ref>{{cite news|last=Fehd|first=Amanda|url=http://www.foxnews.com/printer_friendly_wires/2008Feb04/0,4675,IndustryStandard,00.html|title=Industry Standard Returns, Online Only|publisher=Associated Press (via foxnews.com)|date=February 4, 2008| accessdate=October 17, 2013}}</ref> In 2010, ''The Industry Standard'' became a "channel" within InfoWorld, another publication owned by IDG.<ref>{{cite news|first=Eric|last=Knorr|first2=Ian|last2=Lamont|url=http://www.infoworld.com/d/the-industry-standard/welcome-readers-the-industry-standard-170|title=Welcome, readers of the Industry Standard!|date=March 26, 2010|accessdate=April 24, 2010}}</ref>
